Name: Geoff Brown
Top Critics Reviews: For all the sluggish script and the enormous weight of the special effects, this movie behemoth still has the power to shake us rigid and and touch the soul.

Name: Nigel Andrews
Top Critics Reviews: [The ending] is a masterpiece of popcorn tragedy: not deep, not sophisticated, barely even credible, but gut-clutching for those of us who have already lost the sensible use of our stomachs, as we would in any worthwhile fairground ride.

Name: Quentin Curtis
Top Critics Reviews: The movie is a ride, and not without the odd moment of corniness. But it's also about freedom and flight, bondage and stagnation. And most fittingly, as a memorial itself, it's about memory and the act of remembering.

Name: Duane Byrge
Top Critics Reviews: No meager disaster movie, greased by generic formula and goosed by big-bucks technology... Titanic is one big, bruising movie that will appeal on different levels to different audiences.

Name: Jack Mathews
Top Critics Reviews: Cameron's aim was to set the most intimate love story possible against one of the century's biggest tragedies, and he very nearly pulls it off. DiCaprio has a captivating presence in a role that might have been written for a young Clark Gable.

Name: Alissa Wilkinson
Top Critics Reviews: What I can tell you, risking puns, is that it swept me off my feet almost from the get-go, a grand epic romance-disaster that reminded me, in the middle of my overstuffed-with-movies life, of what we mean when we talk about the power of cinema.

Name: Jason Bailey
Top Critics Reviews: Sure, 'Titanic' may be corny, clumsy, and obvious-but the sincerity of its emotions and the power of its spectacle endure.

Name: Paul Tatara
Top Critics Reviews: Cameron has devised a tender love story between Kate Winslet and Leonardo DiCaprio that serves as the main focus of Titanic's storyline, and it works beautifully.

Name: Dave Kehr
Top Critics Reviews: If computer-generated special effects have overpowered human-generated drama, Cameron seizes that dangerously cold technology and recasts it as dream and delirium, profoundly human in its sources and longings.

Name: Desmond Ryan
Top Critics Reviews: The execution is state-of-the-art and breathtaking. Titanic offers the full compass of courage and cowardice, and it stands as an achievement that truly is a night to remember at the movies.

Name: Maria Schneider
Top Critics Reviews: Titanic provides an absorbing blend of historical fact and old-fashioned Hollywood tearjerking.

Name: Jay Boyar
Top Critics Reviews: Titanic is indeed a ship of dreams. Climb aboard and bon voyage.

Name: Joe Holleman
Top Critics Reviews: Take one of history's most compelling tragedies, tell it through the lives of two engaging young lovers and show it with some of the best-ever special effects and you have a dazzling, exciting movie that is also poignant and personal.

Name: Gene Siskel
Top Critics Reviews: With his beatific, sweet, open face, DiCaprio gives us a rooting interest in hoping that someone important to us survives the wreck.

Name: Cath Clarke
Top Critics Reviews: We know the story ends badly but Cameron still sweeps us up in the romance between Kate Winslet's rebellious posh girl and DiCaprio's steerage kid.

Name: David Sexton
Top Critics Reviews: It has itself become, like the shipwreck, a cultural monument, only accreting value, not losing significance, as time goes by.

Name: Dana Stevens
Top Critics Reviews: Cameron's three-hour disaster epic is a triumph of popular art -- of folk art, really.

Name: Rafer Guzman
Top Critics Reviews: "Titanic" still amazes as the kind of massive, build-and-destroy production that few filmmakers have the ambition or budget to make.

Name: Ann Hornaday
Top Critics Reviews: [Cameron] stages the sinking with a flawless sense of detail, pacing, import and dread.

Name: Alonso Duralde
Top Critics Reviews: For all of its flaws, this movie works in the way that classic Hollywood movies do. It delivers.

Name: Peter Bradshaw
Top Critics Reviews: Only the snobbish or the obtuse could deny its ambition, verve and entertainment firepower.

Name: Joe Morgenstern
Top Critics Reviews: This version has deepened and enriched a film that was already rich in emotions and remarkable for its depth of detail.

Name: Peter Travers
Top Critics Reviews: How is Titanic in 3D? The answer is pretty damn dazzling.

Name: Basia Cummings
Top Critics Reviews: If you fancy indulging in pure, unadulterated silliness and spending a night in the '90s, this is a good bet. Otherwise...

Name: Michael Phillips
Top Critics Reviews: Cameron is a genius at instilling narrative dread and designing a hokum-drenched fairy tale of a certain size.

Name: Christy Lemire
Top Critics Reviews: If any film should be redone in 3-D, it's "Titanic." And if any filmmaker should be the one doing the redoing, it's James Cameron.

Name: Philip De Semlyen
Top Critics Reviews: With a 3D conversion from the medium's pioneer-in-chief, Titanic is a big-screen romance that's every bit as epic as you remember.

Name: R. Kurt Osenlund
Top Critics Reviews: The re-release is keenly timed with the 100th anniversary of the actual sinking of the RMS Titanic, yet another factor to validate the 3D film's existence.

Name: Claudia Puig
Top Critics Reviews: Sure, it's corny, but there's something endearing about the tale of young love and its earnest lack of irony.

Name: Robbie Collin
Top Critics Reviews: Cameron's detractors grouse about his use of scale and spectacle to invest archetypal, even clichd stories with an extra, unearned emotional significance. They're absolutely right, with one crucial caveat: there's absolutely nothing unearned about it.

Name: Joe Neumaier
Top Critics Reviews: Like Kathy Bates' "unsinkable" Molly Brown, "Titanic" is unabashedly American: It's big, brash and sometimes gauche, yet also unapologetically earnest, amazing to look at and devoted to its own cause. And it knows how to win us over.

Name: Liam Lacey
Top Critics Reviews: Overall, for a blockbuster movie about one great big thing hitting another great big thing, the new film shows distinctly upper-deck restraint.

Name: Peter Howell
Top Critics Reviews: The letdown factor has been most keenly felt in conversions from 2D, but Titanic 3D shows how the ambition can be realized if the will and skill are there. We can only hope that other filmmakers follow Cameron's example.

Name: Nick Pinkerton
Top Critics Reviews: But the power of Titanic didn't come from originality; it came from punching clichs across with a seldom-seen directness and sincerity that seemed pure of heart, "old-fashioned," or plain corny, depending on your perspective.

Name: Lou Lumenick
Top Critics Reviews: James Cameron's spectacular new 3-D version of "Titanic'' is everything I'd hoped for, and more.

Name: Rene Rodriguez
Top Critics Reviews: Here is a rare opportunity to return to something you once loved, and discover it still holds up, no apologies necessary.

Name: Paul Byrnes
Top Critics Reviews: Turns out hubris and greed float, like sorrow.

Name: David Edelstein
Top Critics Reviews: Now it can be told: The Titanic went down because of two distracting smoochers on the poop deck.

Name: Todd McCarthy
Top Critics Reviews: A spectacular demonstration of what modern technology can contribute to dramatic storytelling.

Name: Desson Thomson
Top Critics Reviews: Titanic is a good, often stunning movie caught in a three-and-a-half hour drift.

Name: Stephen Hunter
Top Critics Reviews: This is Cameron at his best.

Name: David Ansen
Top Critics Reviews: Titanic is big, bold, touchingly uncynical filmmaking.

Name: Andrew Sarris
Top Critics Reviews: Titanic runs well enough in the backstretch of intrigue and contrivance to cross the finish line well ahead of all but a few of the screen's superspectacles in this century.

Name: Steven D. Greydanus
Top Critics Reviews: Perhaps the most melancholy thing about Titanic is its celebration of romantic ideals to the exclusion of such self-denying virtues as honor, duty, and heroism.

Name: Geoff Andrew
Top Critics Reviews: Cost: well over $200m. Disregarding the ethics of such expenditure on a film, this unprecedented extravagance has not resulted in sophisticated or even very satisfying storytelling.

Name: Douglas Pratt
Top Critics Reviews: A grand and classy production.

Name: Eric Henderson
Top Critics Reviews: It's something of an ingenuous revision of the standard disaster movie.

Name: Rick Groen
Top Critics Reviews: Titanic is awesome even when it's awful -- you can't take your eyes off the extraordinary thing.

Name: Almar Haflidason
Top Critics Reviews: Despite its failings it's hard not to become swept up in the sheer grandeur of Titanic.

Name: Kenneth Turan
Top Critics Reviews: A hackneyed, completely derivative copy of old Hollywood romances, a movie that reeks of phoniness and lacks even minimal originality.

Name: Jay Carr
Top Critics Reviews: Titanic is big-budget spectacle and director Cameron brings it off with high-tech bravura, placing us aboard the ship in real time.

Name: Mike Clark
Top Critics Reviews: Credit Cameron for locating that latitude-longitude spot where haunting loss intersects with sheer cinematic braggadocio. His movie may not be perfect, but visually and viscerally, it pretty well is.

Name: James Berardinelli
Top Critics Reviews: You don't just watch Titanic, you experience it.

Name: Marc Savlov
Top Critics Reviews: It's still by far and away a grand, gorgeous, breathtaking spectacle.

Name: John Hartl
Top Critics Reviews: No other film has made the horror of the ship's sinking so palpable, and none other has dared to dramatize the night of the living dead that followed after it sank beneath the North Atlantic.

Name: Stephanie Zacharek
Top Critics Reviews: Glub glub glub.

Name: Jonathan Rosenbaum
Top Critics Reviews: All things considered, Titanic is old-fashioned epic filmmaking that carries a wallop.

Name: Roger Ebert
Top Critics Reviews: James Cameron's 194-minute, $200 million film of the tragic voyage is in the tradition of the great Hollywood epics. It is flawlessly crafted, intelligently constructed, strongly acted and spellbinding.

Name: Michael Wilmington
Top Critics Reviews: Titanic is a film that sweeps us away into a world of spectacle, beauty and excitement.

Name: Owen Gleiberman
Top Critics Reviews: A lush and terrifying spectacle of romantic doom.

Name: Janet Maslin
Top Critics Reviews: Cameron succeeds magically in linking his film's young lovers, played enchantingly by Leonardo DiCaprio and Kate Winslet.

Name: Nell Minow
Top Critics Reviews: The movie raises important questions about choices faced by the characters.

Name: Adam Smith
Top Critics Reviews: James Cameron has gone and delivered a spectacular, moving, utterly engrossing three-and-a-bit hour epic.

Name: Jeff Millar
Top Critics Reviews: Titanic will give you your money's worth.

Name: Tom Keogh
Top Critics Reviews: The would-be emotional centerpiece of his three-hours-plus adventure flick is the most juvenile romantic tale of 1997.

Name: Peter Rainer
Top Critics Reviews: There's a lot to like here.

Name: Peter Brunette
Top Critics Reviews: The disaster is definitely worth the wait.

Name: Stanley Kauffmann
Top Critics Reviews: Bursting through gaps in the hull, rushing down corridors, licking at rooms, triumphing over great ballrooms and tiny closets, down stairways and into elevators, the sea, in the hands of Cameron and his technical associates, becomes hungry, vindictive.

Name: Robert Horton
Top Critics Reviews: Like it or hate it, Titanic lives and breathes as a piece of pure cinema.

Name: Susan Stark
Top Critics Reviews: As spectacle, Titanic sets a new standard; as romantic drama, it's substandard.

Name: Mick LaSalle
Top Critics Reviews: The last hour of Titanic is huge and staggering, but there's no horror in it.

Name: Richard Corliss
Top Critics Reviews: The regretful verdict here: dead in the water.
